#Text=Wikinews interviews Dr. Robert Kelly and Dr. Jim Gill regarding joint scientific venture in North Korea
#Text=Sunday , September 8 , 2013
#Text=File : Robert Kelly
#Text=File Photo . JPG
#Text=File photo of Dr. Robert Kelly .
#Text=Image : Robert Kelly .
#Text=( Image missing from commons : image ; log )
#Text=A group of volcanologists from the UK and USA have traveled to North Korea to assist them with conducting scientific investigations and installing equipment near the volcano Mount Paektu .

#Text=Wikinews interviewed Dr. Robert Kelly of Pusan National University ( PNU ) in South Korea , who specialises in security and diplomacy and Dr. Jim Gill from the University of California who has visited the Chinese side of Mount Paektu .
#Text=Dr. Robert Kelly
#Text=( ( Wikinews ) )
#Text=Given that the UK , USA have strained political relations with North Korea , what is the purpose of these scientists working together ?
#Text=Dr. Robert Kelly :
#Text=Mt Paektu erupted massively about 1100 years ago and has been dormant since .
#Text=Recently there has been seismic activity , and should it explode again , it could be gigantic — and devastating .
#Text=It is everyone 's interest in East Asia to know about such a possibility , so this kind of cooperation can be above politics .
#Text=But it is also always good to engage North Korea to try to draw them out .
#Text=Such engagement can occur in nonpolitical , technical areas like this most easily .
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=Does North Korea understand that it needs the specialism of British and American scientists to plan for when the volcano erupts ?
#Text=RK : It does .
#Text=North Korea does actually engage in various track II programming , including student and administrative exchanges .
#Text=This is not well-known due to the nuclear issue however .
#Text=The North Korean government is aware of its technological backwardness , and they often dangle concessions to other states in exchange for tech transfers like this .
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=The North Korea underground nuclear test site is very close to the volcano , do you think this affected North – South Korean relations ?
#Text=RK : Not very much .
#Text=It does upset South Koreans somewhat , because Mt . Paektu is actually [ a ] national landmark .
#Text=It is the mythological birthplace of the Korean people .
#Text=And there is some scientific concern that major seismic activity could impact nuclear facilities .
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=Do you think that the field work being carried out by the scientists , being near a militarised border is very difficult ?
#Text=RK :
#Text=No , because it is in the interest of all local parties — NK , Chinese , even Russian — that Mt . Paektu is properly monitored .
#Text=Indeed , I could imagine that , behind the scenes , the Chinese pushed North Korea toward this cooperation , as this is somewhat unusual for NK .
#Text=A file photo of Mount Paektu .
#Text=Image : Bdpmax .
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=May the North Koreans be wary and suspicious of their British and American counterparts , given the secretiveness of the state ?
#Text=RK : Absolutely .
#Text=I have been to NK , and I can say positively that the scientists will be monitored and accompanied at all times they are away from their hotels .
#Text=They will also be isolated from the NK wider population .
#Text=They will only interact with specially chosen minders who speak excellent English and have proven their loyalty to the state .
#Text=And there will be security personnel with them at all times outside their hotels too .
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=Do you think that Western scientists collaborating together with the North Koreans could set as an example of political things to see in the future ?
#Text=RK : Not really .
#Text=I hope so , but North Korean[sic ] has a tendency to pretend to open itself , and then to re-close after it gets what it wants .
#Text=All sorts of interaction with North Korea gets hyped as ' a new beginning ' or a ' historic opening , ' only to come to naught .
#Text=That does not mean it could not happen , just that I am skeptical .
#Text=Instead , NK is likely to continue to interact when and where it has certain specific needs , as in this case .
#Text=And that interaction will be tightly monitored .
#Text=Fifteen years [ ago ] , at the start of the Sunshine Policy by SK , there was hope that increased interaction would grow organically and slowly open up NK .
#Text=That was the spirit behind the Kaesong industrial zone .
#Text=But in fact , the North Koreans tightly controlled Kaesong to capture its gains and limit spillovers .
#Text=I imagine the same will happen here .
#Text=Dr. Jim Gill
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=Do natural hazards pay attention to international political differences ?
#Text=Dr. Jim Gill : Of course not .
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=Is there a high risk and increased seismic activity in relation to Mount Paektu ?
#Text=JG : Not currently .
#Text=There was unrest at the volcano during 2002 – 05 but it has returned to normalcy .
#Text=( ( WN ) )
#Text=Would an eruption of Mount Paektu have consequences for multiple countries ?
#Text=JG :
#Text=Yes .
#Text=The most likely widespread consequence will be an interuption of air traffic between North Asia and North America and Europe .
#Text=More locally , the tourist industry on the Chinese side of the border will be very impacted .
#Text=Most ash fall will be in the DPRK .
#Text=For perspective , there was an extremely large eruption of the volcano at about 940 AD — one of the largest historical eruptions anywhere on Earth .
#Text=It is uncertain how often it has erupted since , and how large the eruptions were , but nothing has been big enough to cause serious problems scores of kilometers away .
#Text=So yes there is risk — it is large mountain with a long history of eruptions — but nothing indicates a high level of concern now .
